title-group.article-title: A new protein-dependent riboswitch activates ribosomal frameshifting

abstract.p: Programmed –1 ribosomal frameshifting (PRF) is a ubiquitous translational control mechanism in RNA viruses, allowing them to change the relative abundance of proteins encoded in different reading frames. The cardioviruses exhibit the highest known viral PRF efficiency in nature, with up to 85 % of ribosomes diverted into the –1 frame. This unusual event requires an interaction between the viral 2A protein and a regulatory element in the RNA genome, thus PRF is conditionally activated by 2A accumulation during infection. Here we present the structure of the 2A-RNA complex, revealing a novel pseudoknot architecture and illustrating the mechanism of 2A recognition. By combining single-molecule Förster resonant energy transfer (smFRET) and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), we demonstrate that the RNA does not pre-exist as a pseudoknot, rather 2A binding induces a striking conformational change from a stem-loop into a pseudoknot. Together, this defines the conformational landscape of a protein-dependent riboswitch, revealing new mechanistic principles that underpin viral gene expression. We suggest that PRF stimulatory elements in other viruses may also be regulated in a similar way, highlighting their potential as targets for new antiviral drugs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Programmed –1 ribosomal frameshifting (PRF) is a translational control mechanism that underpins the replication cycle of hundreds of medically and agriculturally important RNA viruses (reviewed in 1–3). Collectively, the clinical, social and economic impact of viruses exploiting PRF is enormous. Examples include human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1, ~1.3 million new infections per year4), severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2, ~760 million cases and ~6.9 million deaths5), Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV, ~100,000 infections and ~25,000 deaths per year6) and porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV, ~$664 million annual loss in the USA alone7).

During a –1 frameshift event, elongating ribosomes are diverted one nucleotide backwards into an alternative reading frame at a specific position on the viral RNA, leading to the translational fusion of polypeptides encoded by the upstream ‘0 frame’ and downstream ‘–1 frame’ sequences8,9. The frameshift efficiency is usually fixed, producing an optimal ratio of 0 frame to – 1 frame proteins for efficient virus replication and assembly. Maintaining a precise frameshifting efficiency is therefore crucial for viral fitness, and sequences directing PRF are highly conserved. Moreover, PRF is not widely used as a gene expression strategy by the host, making it an attractive target for antiviral therapeutics10–12.

Frameshifting typically requires two elements. First, a heptameric ‘slippery sequence’ of the form X_XXY_YYZ (where X is any nucleotide, Y is A or U, and Z is any nucleotide except G) permits codon-anticodon base pairing in both 0 (X_XXY_YYZ) and –1 (XXX_YYY) frames. Secondly, a structured RNA ‘stimulatory element’ (usually a pseudoknot or stem-loop) located 5 to 9 nucleotides downstream acts as a mechanical barrier, resisting unwinding by ribosomal helicase proteins uS3, uS4 and uS5 that encircle the mRNA entry channel13,14. Ribosomes slow down or pause when they encounter the stimulatory element15–18, positioning the slippery sequence in the P and A sites, and causing tension to develop in the RNA19. Tandem slippage of tRNAs likely occurs during subsequent translocation attempts (reviewed in 20). In reconstituted prokaryotic systems, RNA stimulatory elements slow down translocation, prolonging the duration of rotated hybrid and chimeric states, and impairing reverse swivel of the small subunit head. This is accompanied by slow release of EF-G and delayed dissociation of deacylated E site tRNA, or multiple unproductive cycles of EF-G binding21,22. During this delay, tRNAs may spontaneously and reversibly fluctuate between reading frames, reaching an equilibrium based on the relative free energies of pairing in the 0 and –1 frames22,23.

RNA stimulatory elements present an intriguing paradox, with many — and often conflicting — features linked to their ability to promote frameshifting. Despite being protein-coding sequences, they must be stable enough to pose a barrier to elongation, whilst unwinding at physiologically achievable forces during translocation (~13 pN)24. Early work suggested that overall thermodynamic stability of the stimulatory element would correlate with PRF efficiency, however substitution with heterologous sequences of equivalent stability did not stimulate frameshifting25. Subsequent structural work on diverse viral PRF stimulatory pseudoknots revealed complex structural features hypothesised to be important, including minor groove triplex interactions between stem 1 (S1) and loop 3 (L3)26–30, unusual geometry such as base triples, quadruples or bending at the S1/S2 junction31–33 and ‘threading’ of the 5′ end in the SARS-CoV-2 pseudoknot34–36. Recently, a cryo-EM study revealed specific interactions between the SARS-CoV-2 pseudoknot and components of the 80S ribosomal helicase37, supporting the theory that frameshifting is driven by specific RNA structure. Alternatively, it has been proposed that frameshifting is driven by the existence of multiple interconverting conformations that are sampled by a stimulatory element38–41. These ideas can be difficult to reconcile with high-resolution structures of stimulatory elements, which are necessarily static snapshots of a single RNA conformer. This is further confounded by the inaccuracy of deep-learning-based RNA structure prediction tools42.

Another layer of complexity is presented by cellular and viral proteins, which can either inhibit43–45 or stimulate46–49 PRF. A striking case of the latter occurs in the cardioviruses (family Picornaviridae), with up to 85 % of ribosomes shifting into the –1 frame at a conserved G_GUU_UUU slippery sequence in Theiler’s murine encephalitis virus (TMEV)50–52 (Figure 1a-c). This is the highest known efficiency viral PRF event in nature, but is unusual for several reasons. First, it is entirely conditional on the presence of the virally encoded 2A protein, which binds to an RNA stimulatory element located 13–14 nt downstream50,51. Secondly, although this element is predicted to form a seven base pair stem-loop, mutagenesis studies suggest that none of the essential nucleotides reside within the stem52. Instead, a pair of guanines in the flanking 5′ region and a cytosine triplet in the loop are essential for 2A binding and frameshifting. Finally, the positioning of this element deviates significantly from the canonical 5 to 9 nt spacer — seemingly too far away to pause the ribosome over the slippery sequence. We previously hypothesised that the cardiovirus stimulatory element may instead form an RNA pseudoknot, which 2A selectively recognises52,53. However, this does not adequately explain the protein-dependency of PRF, and structures of 2A proteins from encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) and TMEV reveal no homology to any known RNA-binding fold52,53. Thus, the molecular mechanisms underpinning cardiovirus PRF activation remain elusive.

Here, we combine X-ray crystallography, small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) and single molecule Förster Resonant Energy Transfer (smFRET) to examine the structure and dynamics of the TMEV stimulatory element in the presence and absence of 2A protein. We first determine a 1.9 Å structure of the 2A-RNA complex, revealing a compact RNA pseudoknot with a novel two-stem architecture. We next demonstrate that the RNA stimulatory element behaves as a protein-dependent riboswitch, undergoing a dramatic conformational rearrangement from a seven base pair stem-loop to a pseudoknot upon 2A binding. Our structure explains the protein dependence of pseudoknot formation, via arginine-mediated stabilisation of a distorted three base pair stem. Finally, we dissect the sequence specificity of this unique molecular switch. Together, this work defines the conformational repertoire of a new protein-dependent riboswitch and demonstrates that — even though cardiovirus PRF elements are indeed conformationally plastic — one stable conformation is likely the major determinant of PRF. We suggest that frameshifting signals in other viruses may be similarly regulated by as-yet-unidentified proteins or ligands, explaining some of the reported conformational heterogeneity and emphasising the potential of PRF elements as drug targets.

sec.title: The PRF stimulatory element from TMEV is a protein-pseudoknot complex
sec.p: Our work to understand the molecular basis of PRF in the cardioviruses began with structural studies of the stimulatory element from TMEV. We determined the X-ray crystal structure of a complex between TMEV 2A protein (amino acids 1–133, corresponding to 921-1053 of the TMEV polyprotein) and a minimal RNA stimulatory element (nucleotides 14–47 in Figure 1b, corresponding to 4248-4281 of the TMEV genome). The structure was refined at 1.9 Å resolution (PDB 9RVP, Table S1) revealing that the RNA adopts a novel pseudoknot conformation when bound to 2A protein (Figure 1d and movie S1). 2A adopts the same globular ‘beta-shell’ architecture as the apo structure53 (Figure S1a, Cα backbone RMSD of 0.39 Å over 125 residues).

The RNA pseudoknot comprises two non-coaxially stacked stems in an unusual side-by-side arrangement, with a tilt of ~55° between their helical axes. (Figure 2 and Figure S1b). Stem 1 (S1) consists of three Watson-Crick G-C base pairs between highly conserved GGxG and CCC triplet motifs, providing a structural basis to the previous biochemical characterisation49–53. Interestingly, the three guanosine nucleotides (G17, G18 and G20) comprising S1 are not consecutive, and U19 is flipped out by S1 formation. This results in an unusual helical geometry: the first two G-C base pairs (G17-C38 and G18-C37) exhibit a typical helical twist of ~36.2°, but the final base pair (G20-C36) has a twist of ~50.6° relative to G18-C37 (Figure S1c) causing compression of the major groove.

Such geometry is unfavourable, but S1 is stabilised by the insertion of the 2A ‘arginine loop’ into the major groove (Figure 2, movie S1). The guanidinium groups of R87 and R85 are approximately coplanar with the second (G18-C37) and third (G20-C36) base pairs of S1 respectively, resembling base triples. The network of interactions can be described by two ‘arginine forks’ — recurrent structural motifs in protein-RNA interactions54–56. R87 stabilises the second base pair of S1 (G18-C37) via interactions between Nη atoms and the Hoogsteen edge of G18, and a hydrogen bond between the Nε atom and a ribonucleotide phosphate oxygen of G17 (HηηP fork). R85 stabilises the third base pair of S1 (G20-C36) via interactions between Nη2 and Nε atoms and the Hoogsteen edge of G20, and between Nη2 and the ribose 2' hydroxyl of G18 (HS fork). On the other side of G20, the carbonyl oxygen of glycine 27 forms a hydrogen bond with N2, such that this guanine base is “clamped” between R85 and G27. Comparison to the apo structure of TMEV 2A illustrates how glycine 27 moves 1.6 Å towards G20 while the guanidinium group of R85 rotates: we therefore refer to this as the “G-clamp” interaction (Figure S1a). This third base pair (G20-C36) is further supported by packing against the surface of the 2A beta-sheet, comprising residues R7, D9, F11 from β1, H67 from β4 and K24 from β2, the latter of which forms a hydrogen bond with the ribose 2' hydroxyl of G20. Immediately prior to S1, the 5′ end of the stimulatory RNA also interacts with the surface of 2A, with A15 stacking against W89 (Figure 2 and movie S1). Together, these interactions bury a surface of 634 Å2.

Downstream of S1, loop 1 (L1) is a single nucleotide (C21) leading into stem 2 (S2), a seven base pair A-form RNA helix (C22 – A28; U39 – G45) (Figure 2 and movie S1). These base pairs are consistent with previous bioinformatic predictions and structure probing experiments50,51. S2 is connected to the 3′ strand of S1 by loop 2 (L2, A29 – U35, Figure 2). However, the electron density for L2 is poor (Figure 2 and movie S1) demonstrating that U31, A32 and A33 are flexible or disordered. Nevertheless, A29 and C30 stack against A28 from S2, and weak density suggests that A34 may stack against C38 from S1. Loop 3, a hallmark of canonical H-type pseudoknots57, is entirely absent.

sec.title: The 2A-pseudoknot interaction is likely universal in cardioviruses
sec.p: AlphaFold358 was unable to predict this complex, instead predicting interactions between 2A protein and S2 (Figure S1d). However, both the S1-forming GGxG and CCC motifs in the RNA and the R85 and R87 residues in 2A protein are highly conserved in cardioviruses52. To explore this further, we turned our attention to EMCV, for which the structure of 2A protein is known53 but the minimal RNA stimulatory element is 10 nt larger (42 nt) than that of TMEV (32 nt) (Figure S2a). Structural alignment of the EMCV 2A apo structure to the 2A-pseudoknot complex reported here showed the RNA binding surface to be nearly identical and compatible with S1 formation (Figure S2b). Strikingly, the required flexibility for the “G-clamp” is also apparent in EMCV: there is a 5.6 Å movement at the required position (G33 in EMCV 2A) between different NCS-related chains in the asymmetric unit. Similarly, EMCV residues R97 and R95 are optimally positioned to interact with the second and third base pairs of S1, respectively. By manually enforcing the formation of S1 base pairs, we used SimRNA59 to predict the structure of the EMCV pseudoknot (Figure S2c). The resultant model shares many features with the TMEV pseudoknot, with a side-by-side arrangement of S1 (3 bp) and S2 (7 bp), and a flipped-out A19 base in S1. The additional 10 nucleotides in EMCV correspond to an extended L2 sequence, which is predicted to form a tetraloop-capped 4 bp stem that coaxially stacks against S2. The absence of L1 in EMCV, but the introduction of an L3 (U48) alters the angle between S1 and S2, making the helical axes almost parallel. However, manual docking of this predicted RNA onto the apo structure of EMCV 2A illustrates that the principles of RNA recognition are identical (Figure S2d). Overall, our crystallographic analysis reveals that the TMEV PRF stimulatory element is a novel protein-pseudoknot complex that is likely conserved in all cardioviruses.

sec.title: The RNA stimulatory element switches conformation upon 2A binding
sec.p: Having determined that the RNA is a pseudoknot in complex with 2A, we asked whether this pseudoknot could form by itself in solution. To do this, we employed size exclusion chromatography coupled with small angle X-ray scattering (SEC-SAXS) to generate a molecular envelope of the RNA in isolation (Table S2). The sample was monodisperse, with a radius of gyration (Rg) of ~2 nm and maximum particle dimension (Dmax) of ~8 nm. However, these data are better explained by a 7 bp stem-loop (Figure 3a, χ2 = 1.1) and not the pseudoknot conformation observed in our crystal structure (χ2 = 13.9, Figure S3a). We next analysed the 2A-RNA complex by SEC-SAXS and found it to be in good agreement with the X-ray crystal structure (Rg ~2.2 nm, Dmax ~7.5 nm, χ2 = 1.1, Figure 3b). These results suggested that the RNA may undergo a large conformational rearrangement upon 2A binding.

Previously we had hypothesised that the RNA may sample a repertoire of different conformations in solution53. Stem-loops and pseudoknots may coexist in equilibrium, or alternatively the pseudoknot conformation could be uniquely induced by 2A binding. With this in mind, we decided to conduct smFRET experiments on freely diffusing molecules to explore the conformations sampled by the frameshifting RNA in detail. We designed two FRET reporter RNAs with the Cy5/Cy3 FRET pair: an ‘end reporter’ labelled with 5' Cy5 and 3' Cy3 fluorophores (Figure 3c and Figure S3c), and an ‘internal reporter’ labelled with 5' Cy5 and an internal Cy3 fluorophore attached to U31 within L2 of the pseudoknot (Figure 3d and Figure S3d). These were designed to minimally impact RNA folding, avoid dye quenching by adjacent guanine bases, and give distinct FRET efficiencies in both stem-loop and pseudoknot conformations. The use of alternating-laser excitation (ALEX) confocal imaging60 allowed for discrimination between singly-labelled and doubly-labelled FRET-active forms, enabling us to exclusively conduct our downstream analyses on bona fide FRET events.

The end reporter RNA exhibited one major high-FRET species (Figure 3e and Figure S4, E = 0.96 ± 0.01, ~31 Å between dyes), consistent with a stem-loop conformation. A second minor FRET population (E = 0.86 ± 0.03, ~39 Å between dyes) could indicate mobility of the 5′ single-stranded region in some molecules (Figure S3b). In the presence of 2A, we observe a single FRET population reflecting a single conformation adopted by the RNA. The decrease in FRET efficiency (E = 0.63 ± 0.01) is accompanied by a broadening of the FRET distribution, consistent with the ends moving further apart (~49 Å) and becoming more mobile. This agrees with the crystal structure of the RNA pseudoknot, in which neither the 5′ nor 3′ ends of the RNA are stabilised by protein. We do not observe this mid-FRET population (E = 0.63 ± 0.01) in the RNA-only measurements, suggesting that in the absence of 2A, the RNA does not sample the pseudoknot conformation. FRET measurements of the internal reporter RNA resulted in a single, mid-FRET population (E = 0.58 ± 0.00) (Figure 3f and Figure S5). This is consistent with a stem-loop conformation in which the dyes are positioned ~50 Å apart. Upon addition of 2A, we observe a shift to a major high FRET population (E = 0.83 ± 0.01) as the dyes move closer together (~41 Å) during pseudoknot formation. The FRET distribution also narrows, implying that complex formation stabilises the position of the internal dye. A minor second FRET population is also induced by 2A binding (E = 0.67 ± 0.02, ~47 Å). To demonstrate that these changes in FRET efficiency are due to specific interactions with 2A protein and not artefacts of molecular crowding, we performed control experiments with inactive 2AR85A/R87A protein harbouring arginine loop mutations. For both reporters, addition of 2AR85A/R87A results in FRET populations identical to RNA-only experiments (Figure 3e, f). We also confirmed that ionic strength or identity (Na+, K+, Mg2+) has no effect on the conformation of the RNA (Figure S6).

Given that conformational plasticity of stimulatory elements has been proposed to regulate frameshifting38–41, we were interested by the observation of minor FRET populations in some of our datasets (Figure 3e, f). We therefore implemented burst variance analysis (BVA)61 to further examine dynamics in each experiment. Briefly, BVA compares the standard deviation of FRET from individual molecules over the timescale of diffusion to the theoretical shot-noise distribution. Our results with both reporters confirm that the RNA does not spontaneously sample multiple stable conformations (Figure 4). The end reporter RNA is generally more dynamic than the internal reporter RNA, as indicated by the standard deviation being greater than expected from shot-noise. However, this is likely a feature of dye placement rather than a physiologically relevant characteristic.

Overall, our SAXS and FRET analysis support a model in which the stimulatory RNA behaves like a binary switch between two major states. It exists as a stem-loop in isolation, but flips into a pseudoknot in the presence of 2A. Binding of 2A is always accompanied by pseudoknot formation.

sec.title: Pseudoknot formation strictly depends on stem 1 sequence
sec.p: Having established the existence of a new protein-dependent pseudoknot, we wanted to dissect the molecular rules that govern its formation. To do this, we created a series of mutant RNAs and assessed their binding to 2A by electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) and microscale thermophoresis (MST). We first tested the importance of the specific arginine-guanine interactions observed in the structure (Figure 2 and movie S1). Mutations were designed to preserve S1 base pairing and the unusual helical geometry (including the flipped-out base) but remove the possibility of direct arginine-guanine contacts (Figure 5a). These included a complete stem swap, and substitution of guanines with purines and pyrimidines (AU and UA stems). As assessed by EMSA and MST, none of these mutants could efficiently bind to 2A (Figure 5b, c), nor could they stimulate PRF in an in vitro translation experiment (Figure 5d), demonstrating that the arginine loop has strong specificity for guanine. We next tested the effect of deleting the flipped-out base, thus allowing S1 to adopt a more regular conformation. This ΔU19 construct did not detectably bind to 2A but was able to stimulate -1 PRF at very low levels (Figure 5d).

sec.title: Pseudoknot formation depends on stem 2 length, not sequence
sec.p: Similarly, we tested the limits of S2 on pseudoknot formation. S2 mutants included a stem-swap, insertion of an additional base-pair, and deletion of 1 or 2 base-pairs (Figure 6a). The stem-swap RNA could bind 2A with high affinity, similar to wt RNA (Figure 6b, KD ~313 nM, assessed by EMSA). However, the addition or removal of 1 base-pair from S2 (creating a 6 or 8 bp S2) had modest effects on binding affinity of 2A (~313-625 nM KD, assessed by EMSA). The deletion of 2 bp from S2, shortening S2 to a 5 bp RNA helix, completely abolished 2A binding. These results suggest that length rather than sequence identity of S2 is important for pseudoknot formation, with 7 bp optimal but 6 - 8 bp tolerated. The MST data showed a broadly similar trend, but reported lower affinities than EMSA (Figure 6c), possibly due to sample aggregation or interactions with capillary surfaces at micromolar concentrations.

Finally, we tested the relative importance of 2A residues at the pseudoknot interface (Figure 2 and Figure S7). We have previously demonstrated that mutation of R85 and R87 completely abolish both RNA binding and frameshifting52. H26A and R7A mutations had a very mild impact on RNA binding. K24A and W89A exhibited stronger effects, consistent with the specific RNA contacts at these positions, although smFRET experiments and in vitro translation assays showed that each of the four mutations could still trigger pseudoknot formation and stimulate frameshifting (Figure S7d, e). Therefore, the only absolute protein requirement is the conserved 2A arginine loop.

sec.title: The second and third base pairs of stem 1 are critical for pseudoknot formation
sec.p: In almost all PRF stimulatory pseudoknots, the stability of S1 is essential for frameshifting – especially of the first base pair to be encountered by the ribosome 62–64. Our observation that only the second and third base pairs of S1 are stabilised by the arginine loop (Figure 2, movie S1) was therefore unexpected. We wondered whether single nucleotide mutations in S1 would prevent rearrangement into the pseudoknot, and designed a series of smFRET end reporters to evaluate the relative importance of base pairing at all three positions (Figure 7a). Instead of mutating the guanines that make direct interactions with R85 and R87, we targeted the cytosines on the opposite strand. A CCC → GGG mutant served as a control for completely abolishing the formation of the pseudoknot, while C38G, C37G and C36G mutants were selected to disrupt individual base pairs. All S1 mutations were found to abolish 2A binding by EMSA and MST (Figure 7b, c). We explored this further at the single-molecule level with our FRET end reporter RNA (Figure 7d and Figures S8-12). As expected, complete disruption of S1 (GGG mutant) abolishes switching to the pseudoknot upon 2A addition, as did mutation of the second (C37G) and third (C36G) base pairs. However, addition of 2A to the C38G mutant produces a population of molecules with a pseudoknot-like conformation (E = 0.76) in which the 5' and 3' ends are ~44 Å apart. Our inability to detect an interaction by ensemble methods (EMSA, MST) suggests that this is an unstable complex. Thus, the disruption of the first S1 base pair upon ribosome approach might trigger 2A dissociation.

sec.title: A novel RNA pseudoknot architecture
sec.p: Here we define a new class of RNA pseudoknot, the formation of which is strictly conditional upon specific interactions with 2A protein. The inability of AlphaFold3 to predict this complex is perhaps unsurprising42,65: of the ~240,000 experimentally determined structures in the PDB, only ~20,000 contain a nucleic acid component, of which ~2,000 are uniquely RNA. This underscores an urgent need for more experimental structures of diverse RNAs and RNA-protein complexes to better inform deep learning-based approaches.

In the protein-bound state, the TMEV stimulatory element resembles an H-type pseudoknot, with a 3 bp S1 connected to a 7 bp S2. However, our high-resolution structure highlights major differences to canonical PRF pseudoknots. All pseudoknots possess, by definition, two base-paired stems (S1 and S2) connected by single-stranded loops L1, L2, and L366,67. S1/S2 coaxial stacking is usually a feature, exemplified by beet western yellow virus (BWYV26,68), pea enation mosaic virus (PEMV69), potato leaf roll virus (PLRV28), sugarcane yellow leaf virus (ScYLV31) and SARS-CoV-234,35. In these structures, folding is nucleated by a stable 5′ S1 of at least 5 bp, reinforced by tertiary interactions with nucleotides in L3 loops (reviewed in 57). In the TMEV RNA, the absence of L3 makes coaxial stacking of S1/S2 impossible: instead they exist in a side-by-side arrangement, with a ~55° rotation between helical axes, and L2 adenine nucleotides contribute to tertiary interactions with S1.

A key question is why does this novel pseudoknot depend on 2A protein? In RNA-only experiments, our SAXS and smFRET data both indicate that S1 does not form: the molecule exists exclusively as a 7 bp stem-loop (S2) with a flexible 5′ arm. Surprisingly, there is no equilibrium between stem-loop and pseudoknot conformations in the absence of protein — even though the pseudoknot (10 bp, 27 Watson-Crick hydrogen bonds) intuitively appears to be more stable than the stem-loop (7 bp, 18 Watson-Crick hydrogen bonds). Our structure suggests that the answer to this question is related to the sub-optimal geometry of S1. When RNA pseudoknots were first described, three base pairs were proposed as a theoretical minimum for S1 stability66 and our discovery of a flipped-out base within the 3 bp S1 was highly unexpected. The energetic penalty associated with displacement and solvation of U19 likely explains the dependency of S1 formation on favourable arginine-guanine interactions. In this way, 2A can be thought of as a catalyst or chaperone, reducing the energy barrier for the stem-loop to pseudoknot transition. Once formed, the pseudoknot is further stabilised by interactions with 2A (10 bp, 27 Watson-Crick hydrogen bonds, 8 protein-RNA hydrogen bonds, 634 Å2 interface) consistent with a large contribution of ΔH (−10.7 ± 0.13 kcal/mol) to the overall ΔG of 2A binding (−9.8 kcal/mol)52. This explains the ability of the complex to function as a blockade during ribosome elongation.

sec.title: High-efficiency frameshifting in cardioviruses
sec.p: Why is the TMEV frameshift efficiency so high? Numerous biochemical and virological studies have identified the stability of S1 — in particular, the first base pairs of S1 — as a major determinant of frameshifting62–64. A striking feature of the TMEV 2A-RNA complex is that the arginine loop exclusively stabilises the second and third positions of S1, not the first. Furthermore, our smFRET data suggests that transient 2A-RNA interactions may still occur in the absence of the first base-pair. We hypothesise that as the ribosome approaches S1, reversible breaking and reforming of the first base pair may occur before 2A dissociates, thereby creating tension on the mRNA that favours a –1 frameshift. This could contribute to the unusually high PRF efficiency (~85 %) in cardioviruses that cannot be explained by thermodynamic equilibrium models22,23. Additional evidence for mRNA tension in this system comes from the observation that reducing the spacer length by one nucleotide biases the ribosome towards –2 frameshifting51, also observed at the HIV-1 gag/pol site19.

Our structure also resolves a mystery regarding the unusually long spacer between the cardiovirus PRF slippery sequence and the downstream stimulatory element. This was initially reported to be 14 nt based on the bioinformatic identification of S2, and mutagenesis experiments that demonstrated the formation of S2 and its importance for PRF48,50. This led to the proposal that the PRF stimulatory element in TMEV was a stem-loop. However, our discovery of S1 in the 2A-RNA complex reduces the spacer to 9 nt between the end of the GGUUUUU slippery sequence the start of the GGxG motif comprising the 5′ strand of S1. This shorter spacer is comparable to that of other PRF signals2 and is mechanistically consistent with pausing the ribosome whilst the decoding centre is positioned over the slippery sequence. Interestingly, the first contact between 2A and the PRF stimulatory RNA is two nucleotides earlier than S1, with A15 stacking against W89. Although this is not required for 2A binding (Figure S7) it may nevertheless cause steric hindrance and contribute to slowing down elongation as the ribosome approaches the first base pair of S114.

sec.title: A protein-dependent riboswitch?
sec.p: Our smFRET and SAXS data excludes the possibility that the RNA pseudoknot exists on its own in solution, acting as a pre-organised docking platform for 2A. Instead, the RNA behaves as a binary switch, converting from stem-loop to pseudoknot only in the presence of 2A. We therefore propose this element represents a new class of protein-dependent riboswitch. Generally, riboswitches modulate gene expression through interconversion between structurally distinct conformations in response to a ligand (reviewed in 57,70,71). To date, riboswitches have been described for a wide variety of ligands, including nucleotide precursors (pre-queuosine1, preQ172), metabolites (coenzyme B1273, S-adenosylmethionine, SAM74,75), amino acids (lysine76, glycine77, glutamine78) and even tRNAs (T-box79). To our knowledge, this is the first suggestion of a specific protein as the primary ligand, although ribosomal proteins have been shown to modulate the stability of adenine-sensing riboswitches80. Another conceptual difference is that the TMEV PRF RNA exerts its regulatory effect at the level of translation elongation rather than translation initiation or transcription termination.

A feature essential to riboswitches is the stabilisation of the ligand-sensing ‘aptamer’ domain, typically S2, by the cognate ligand. This is common in bacterial riboswitches that regulate translation initiation, as the Shine Dalgarno sequences are occluded within the stabilised S2. In our case the ‘aptamer’ would be the GGxG motif comprising S1, and the ligand would be the arginine loop of 2A. The selectivity for arginine is demonstrated by the complete inability of the 2AR85A/R87A protein to induce switching (Figure 3) and no evidence for spontaneous sampling of the pseudoknot conformation in the absence of protein. This contrasts with the PreQ1 riboswitch, which transiently samples an intrinsically unstable pseudoknot-like fold in the absence of preQ1 ligands81.

In conclusion, this work defines the molecular basis for the highest efficiency viral frameshifting event in nature. Reframing the idea of a PRF stimulatory element as a riboswitch has vast implications. We suggest that many other canonical PRF elements — especially those reported to exhibit multiple conformations — may also be regulated by cellular proteins, viral proteins or metabolites. Indeed, ribosome profiling of cells infected with mouse hepatitis virus (MHV)82, SARS-CoV-283,84 and PRRSV85 has revealed variations in frameshifting over time at PRF signals previously thought to function at a fixed efficiency. Understanding this hidden layer of regulation and defining the conformational landscape of PRF elements at an atomic level will be essential to unlock the full potential of artificial intelligence in designing new ligands to manipulate these elements86,87. Furthermore, we note that the compact size, binary nature and very high specificity of the genetic switch described here make it ideal for synthetic biology and biotechnology applications.

sec.title: Cloning, protein expression and purification
sec.p: TMEV 2A cDNA was amplified by PCR from plasmid pOPT3G-based constructs (previously described in 52) using primer pair 1 detailed in Table S3 and cloned into pOPTHMBP to introduce a TEV protease-cleavable N-terminal His6 MBP tag. Mutant TMEV 2A proteins were prepared by mutagenesis PCR-amplification using the primer pairs 2-5 detailed in Table S3.

Recombinant proteins were produced in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3) pLysS cells. Cultures were grown in 2× TY media supplemented with 100 µg/mL ampicillin and 25 µg/mL chloramphenicol (37°C, 200 rpm). Expression was induced at A600 of ~0.6 with 1.0 mM isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) and continued overnight (200 rpm, 21°C, 16 h). Bacteria were pelleted (4000 × g, 4°C, 20 min), washed in cold 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0 and stored at −20°C. Cells from 2.0 L of culture were thawed in 300 mL of lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 300 mM NaCl, 10 mM imidazole supplemented with 50 µg/mL DNase I and EDTA-free proteases) and lysed using a cell disruptor (27 kPSI, 4°C). The insoluble fraction was pelleted by centrifugation (39,000 × g, 40 min, 4.0°C) and discarded. Supernatant was incubated (1 h, 4°C) with 4.0 mL Ni Sepharose 6 fast flow resin (Cytiva) pre-equilibrated in the same buffer. The resin was washed three times with 200 mL buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 300 mM NaCl, 10 mM imidazole) in a gravity column. The protein was batch eluted with 20 mL of 50 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 300 mM NaCl, 300 mM imidazole. His6-tagged TEV protease (50 µg/mL, prepared in-house) was added to the eluate and was dialysed (3.5K MWCO, 4°C, 16 h) against 2.0 L buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 400 mM NaCl, 1.0 mM DTT). Dialysed proteins were subject to heparin-affinity chromatography to remove nucleic acids and His6-MBP solubility tag. Samples were loaded onto a 10 mL HiTrap Heparin column (Cytiva) at 1 mL/min, washed twice with buffer A (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 400 mM NaCl, 1.0 mM DTT) and eluted with a 0% → 50% gradient of buffer B (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 1.0 M NaCl, 1.0 mM DTT) over 8 CV before stepping to 100% buffer B over 10 CV. Fractions containing the 2A protein were pooled and concentrated in an Amicon Ultra centrifugal filter unit (10K MWCO, 4000 × g) prior to size exclusion chromatography (Superdrex 75 16/600, 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 1.0 M NaCl, 1.0 mM DTT). Purity was assessed by 4-20% gradient SDS-PAGE. Purified protein was used immediately for 2A-RNA complex formation or was concentrated (~3.5 mg/mL, 220 µM), snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C.

sec.title: 2A-RNA complex formation and crystallisation
sec.p: RNA oligonucleotide (oligo 1, detailed in Table S3) was reconstituted in 10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 500 mM NaCl to 2.2 mg/mL (200 µM) determined by measuring absorbance at 260 nm using a Nanodrop spectrophotometer (Thermo). 2A-RNA complex was formed by diluting 2A protein to a final concentration of 500 mM NaCl and adding a 1:1 molar ratio of RNA. Complexes were incubated at room temperature for 20 min prior to buffer exchanging into 10 mM HEPES pH 7.4, 100 mM NaCl, 1.0 mM MgCl2, 1.0 mM DTT and concentrating using an Amicon Ultra centrifugal filter unit (10K MWCO, 4000 × g, 10°C). Complexes were then subjected to size exclusion chromatography (Superdrex 75 16/600, 10°C, 10 mM HEPES pH 7.4, 100 mM NaCl, 1.0 mM MgCl2, 1.0 mM DTT). Complex formation was assessed by SDS-PAGE and urea-PAGE. Fractions containing the 2A-RNA complex were pooled and concentrated (~7.5 mg/mL, 693 µM) as assessed by absorbance at 260 nm. Sitting-drop vapor diffusion experiments were set-up in 96-well MRC plates with 50 µL reservoir solution, 150 nL complex and 150 nL crystallisation buffer at 21°C. Diffraction quality crystals grew in 0.2 M ammonium acetate, 0.1 M Bis-Tris pH 5.9, 19% (w/v) PEG 3350. Ten days after plating, crystals were cryo-protected by the addition of 0.2 µL crystallisation buffer supplemented with 20% (v/v) glycerol, prior to harvesting in nylon loops and flash-cooling by plunging into liquid nitrogen.

sec.title: X-ray data collection, structure determination, refinement and analysis
sec.p: Datasets of 3600 images were recorded at Diamond Light Source, beamline I04 (λ = 0.9537 Å) on an Eiger2 XE 16M detector (Dectris), using 100% transmission, an oscillation range of 0.10° and an exposure time of 0.02s per image. Data were processed with XIA2 automated pipeline88 using XDS89 for indexing and integration and AIMLESS90 for scaling and merging. Processing and refinement statistics are detailed in Table S1. Resolution cut off was decided by CC1/2 values ≥ 0.5 and an I/σ(I) ≥ 2 in the highest resolution shell91. Phasing was done by molecular replacement using PHASER92 using two sequential search models. First a partial solution was obtained by placing the coordinates of the apo TMEV 2A protein (PDB ID: 7NBV), followed by searching the unit cell for an idealised 7 bp A-form RNA helix (corresponding to S2) generated by AlphaFold358. The model was completed manually by iterative cycles of model building using COOT93 and refinement with phenix.refine94. MolProbity95 was used to assess model geometry through the refinement process. Structural figures (cartoon, stick and surface representations) were rendered in PyMol (Schrödinger, LLC)96 and ChimeraX97. Analysis of the RNA pseudoknot geometry was performed using the 3DNA webserver98.

sec.title: Size exclusion chromatography coupled with small angle X-ray scattering (SEC-SAXS)
sec.p: All SAXS experiments were performed coupled to size-exclusion chromatography (SEC-SAXS) at the EMBL P12 beamline at PETRA III (DESY; Hamburg, Germany)99. Scattering data were collected on a Pilatus 6M detector at a sample-detector distance of 3 m and at a wavelength of λ = 0.123983 nm (I(s) vs s, where s = 4πsinθ/λ, and 2θ is the scattering angle). For 2A protein-only samples, it was necessary to use high salt to prevent aggregation. 50 – 100 µL protein at 4.0 mg/ml in 20 mM HEPES pH 7.4, 1.0 M KCl, 2.0 % v/v glycerol, 1.0 mM DTT was injected at a 0.35 ml/min flow rate onto a GE Superdex 75 Increase 5/150 column at 20°C. 143 successive 0.25 second frames were collected through two consecutive SEC-SAXS runs, spanning the sample elution peaks of the protein. For RNA-only samples, 50 μl at 7.1 mg/ml in 20 mM HEPES pH 7.4, 400 mM KCl, 2.0 % v/v glycerol, 1.0 mM DTT was injected as above; 57 successive 0.25 second frames were collected through the SEC-elution peak. The 2A-RNA complex was prepared at 8.0 mg/mL in an identical buffer and injected as above; data were collected over 41 successive 0.25 second frames. Further details are provided in Table S2.

Initial data processing was carried out using CHROMIXS100 and radial averaging from 2D to 1D was performed via the SASFLOW pipeline101. Buffer frames were evaluated for statistical similarity using all pairwise Correlation Map (CorMap)101 p-values, applying a significance threshold (α) of 0.01. Statistically equivalent frames were then averaged to produce the final buffer scattering profile, which was subtracted from the corresponding macromolecular elution peaks. Subtracted data blocks that showed a consistent radius of gyration (Rg) values across the elution profile—assessed via the Guinier approximation—were scaled, compared using CorMap, and averaged to yield the final reduced 1D scattering profiles. All CorMap analyses were conducted using PrimusQT within the ATSAS software suite102. Molecular weight estimations were derived using multiple approaches available in ATSAS, including the Porod volume via datporod102, volume-of-correlation analysis via datvc103, the datmow module104 and the Bayesian consensus method105. Indirect Fourier transformation of the SAXS data was performed using GNOM106 to compute the real-space pair-distance distribution function, p(r) versus r, from which the radius of gyration (Rg) and maximum particle dimension (Dmax) were obtained. Refer to Table S2.

Ab initio dummy atom bead modelling/shape reconstruction was performed using MONSA107, that takes into account differences in the average X-ray scattering length density of protein compared to RNA. Briefly, the 2A protein and RNA-only samples were modelled to their individual scattering profiles as single-phase particles, where the average excess X-ray scattering contrast of each phase was set to 2.413 x1010 cm-2 (2A protein) or 5.580 x1010 cm-2 (RNA) calculated relative to the average scattering length density of the respective sample buffers using MULCh 108. Target phase volumes were set to 21.4 nm3 (2A protein) and 11.2 nm3 (RNA), respectively, based on the amino acid or RNA composition108. The 2A-RNA complex was modelled as a two-phase particle against the 2A protein and 2A-RNA complex SAXS datasets in parallel, using the scattering contrasts and target volumes described above for the protein and RNA phases. MONSA was run five times for each particle reconstruction to qualitatively evaluate shape/volume consistency. Additional single-phase dummy atom modelling for the 2A protein or the 2A-RNA complex was performed using DAMMIN107 using the output from GNOM as input. Following standard protocols109 DAMMIN was run 10 times, the individual models spatially aligned and averaged to develop a consensus shape reconstruction for either sample.

Atomistic models for the RNA were developed using a combination of AlphaFold 3 (AF3)58 (Figure S3b) and normal-mode analysis. The RNA sequence was used as input into AF3 to generate five predicted RNA structures. These individual models underwent subsequent SREFLEX110 normal mode analysis, where the RNA structures were divided up into three rigid bodies that underwent repositioning relative to each other minimizing the fit to the RNA SAXS data (nucleotide ranges: 5′-CCACAA-3′; 5′-GGUGC-3′; 5′-GGUGCUAACUAAAUCCCUAGCACCCC-3′). Of the five initial AF3 models it was found that AF3 model 4 (AF3-4) acted as the best template with respect to generating a fit to the SAXS data after SREFLEX analysis. The post SREFLEX AF3-4 model underwent a second round of SREFLEX modelling to further evaluate the position/conformation of the first six nucleotides that appear as a 5′-overhang and not hybridized within the core RNA stem-loop. The SREFLEX AF3-4 model was divided into two rigid-bodies (5′-CCACAA-3′; 5′-GGUGCGGUGCUAACUAAAUCCCUAGCACCCC-3′) where the first 5′-CCACAA-3′ region underwent systematic manual rotations/translations in PyMol96 to develop seven new SREFLEX AF3-4 based input templates, or alternatively these six 5′-nucleotides were swapped-out with the alternate AF3-predicted structures of the 5′-CCACAA-3′ region derived from AF models 0, 1, 2 and 3. SREFLEX was performed on the 11 new input RNA templates to develop representative individual RNA structures that fit the SAXS data. The introduction of unrealistic gaps in the structures through the course of normal-mode analysis were manually corrected in PyMol.

CORAL rigid body modelling111 was used to generate models of the 2A protein and 2A-RNA complex. In both cases, the structural templates of the protein and RNA components were obtained from the X-ray crystal structure of the 2A-RNA complex (this study, PDB 9RVP). Unresolved RNA nucleotides of the 2A-RNA complex were built using COOT93, while the unresolved/likely flexible N- and C-terminal extensions of the 2A protein component were represented as dummy amino acids (N-terminus: GPLGSNPAS; C-terminus: HDVEMNPGEFPGRLERPHRD). CORAL was run five times against the respective 2A protein or 2A-RNA complex SAXS data to obtain a cohort of protein-alone or protein/RNA structures with alternative spatial positions of the 2A protein N- and C-terminal extensions. The final fit to the SAXS data for all atomistic models was performed using CRYSOL v2.8.3 (30 harmonics, 256 points, constant enabled, average solvent electron density = 0.3416 e/Å3) and assessed by the reduced χ2 test or CorMap p-value. Additional details are provided in Table S2. All subtracted and un-subtracted SEC-SAXS 1D data frames, Rg correlations through the respective SEC-SAXS peaks, as well as MONSA, DAMMIN, SREFLEX and CORAL models and the corresponding model fits are made available in the Small Angle Scattering Biological Databank (SASBDB)112 under the accession codes: SASDWQ5 (2A protein), SASDWR5 (RNA) and SASDWS5 (2A-RNA complex).

sec.title: Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA)
sec.p: RNA oligonucleotides (oligos 4-15, detailed in Table S4) were reconstituted in nuclease-free water to 100 µM. RNAs were labelled at the 5' end with Cy5-maleimide (GE Healthcare) or AzDye647-maleimide (Vector Labs) using the 5' EndTag kit (Vector Labs) according to the manufacturer’s instructions, prior to phenol:chloroform extraction, ethanol precipitation and aqueous resuspension. The concentration of RNA was determined by measuring absorbance at 260 nm using a Nanodrop spectrophotometer (Thermo). 10 µL binding reactions contained 1.0 µL 500 nM fluorescently labelled RNA, 1.0 μL serially diluted 2A protein at concentrations of 0-12.5 µM in 10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 1.0 M NaCl, 1.0 mM DTT, 5.0 μL 2× buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 80 mM NaCl, 4.0 mM magnesium acetate, 2.0 mM DTT, 10 % v/v glycerol and 0.02 % w/v bromophenol blue) and 3.0 μl distilled water. Final concentrations in the binding reactions were 50 nM RNA, 1× buffer, a salt concentration of ~140 mM and 2A protein concentrations of 0-1.25 μM. Samples were incubated at 37°C for 20 mins prior to analysis by non-denaturing 10% acrylamide/TBE PAGE (30 mins, 200 V constant). Gels were imaged with a Typhoon-5 using the 532 and 635 nm lasers/570BP20 and 670BP30 filters.

sec.title: Microscale Thermophoresis (MST)
sec.p: Two-fold dilution series of TMEV 2A wild-type protein or mutants were prepared in SEC buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 1.0 M NaCl, 1.0 mM DTT) producing 2A ligand concentrations ranging from 50 µM to 1.55 nM. For each binding experiment, fluorescently labelled RNA (oligos 4-15, detailed in Table S3) were diluted to 83.3 nm in MST buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 1.67 mM MgCl2, 1.0 mM DTT, 0.083% Tween-20) supplemented with 0.167 mg/ml bovine liver tRNA (Sigma). For the measurement, 2A ligand dilutions were mixed with labelled RNA in a 3:2 ratio, for a final concentration of 50 nM labelled RNA in 20 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 400 mM NaCl, 1.0 mM MgCl2, 1.0 mM DTT, 0.05% Tween-20, 0.1 mg/ml tRNA and a 2A concentration series from 20 µM to 0.61 nM. The reaction was mixed by pipetting, incubated for at least 5 min at room temperature and then held at 4 °C. Capillary forces were used to load the samples into Monolith NT.115 Premium Capillaries (NanoTemper Technologies). Measurements were performed using a Monolith NT.115 instrument (NanoTemper Technologies) at an ambient temperature of 22 °C. Measurements were taken at 20-100% LED power and high MST power. An initial fluorescence scan was performed across the capillaries to determine the sample quality and afterwards 16 subsequent thermophoresis measurements were performed. Data analysis was carried out with an MST on-time of 1.5 seconds to determine binding affinities (MO.Affinity Analysis software, NanoTemper Technologies). Data were fitted to the KD model (single-site binding) using MO.Affinity Analysis software (NanoTemper) using the following equation: f(Cligand)=Unbound+(Bound-Unbound)×Cligand+Ctarget+KD−(Cligand+Ctarget+KD)2−4·Cligand·Ctarget2Ctarget

Where f(Cligand) is the normalised fluoroscence value at a given ligand concentration Cligand. Unbound is the normalised fluoroscence signal of the target alone, Bound is the normalised fluoroscence signal of the complex. KD is the dissociation constant and Ctarget is the final concentration of the target in the assay.

sec.title: Confocal smFRET data acquisition and analysis
sec.p: ‘End reporter’ (5' Cy5, 3' Cy3) and ‘internal reporter’ (5' Cy5, U31 Cy3; oligos 2 and 3 detailed in Table S4) RNA oligonucleotides (IDT) were resuspended to 100 µM in nuclease-free water and stored at -80 °C prior to use. Mutant ‘end reporter’ RNAs (oligos 16-19, detailed in Table S4) were prepared as described above. Samples were diluted to ~12.5 pM RNA in 10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 1.0 mM DTT, 1.0 mM MgCl2 with 0.1 mg/mL BSA. For measurements with 2A protein, 0.5 µM 2A protein was added to the buffer above prior to RNA dilution. smFRET data on freely diffusing molecules was acquired using a confocal-based single-molecule FRET spectrometer (EI-FLEX, Exciting Instruments) equipped with 520 and 638 nm laser lines operating under alternating laser excitation (ALEX). The ALEX cycle period was 100 µs (45 µs donor excitation, 5 µs lasers off, 45 µs acceptor excitation, 5 µs lasers off). 50 µL of sample was placed in a sealed coverslip (# 1) chamber and data recorded for 2 hr at ambient temperature. Biological triplicate measurements were collected and data combined. Analysis was performed in Anaconda 3 with Jupyter Notebooks using FRETBursts113 (version 0.8.3) as described previously114. Briefly, apparent smFRET efficiencies, defined as IA/(IA+ID), where ID and IA are the donor and sensitised acceptor emission intensities under 520 nm excitation were corrected with all four correction parameters as described previously115. For our system correction parameters where: α = 0.08319, δ = 0.06962, γ = 1.12903, β = 1.07552. Molecular stoichiometries, S, were evaluated via (ID + IA) / (ID + IA + IA*), where IA* is the acceptor emission intensity upon direct excitation. After background estimation and subtraction, bursts were identified using an all photon sliding window algorithm as previously described113 with a photon rate of 10 photons (M=10) and a minimum photon rate six times greater than the background rate (F=6). A burst size threshold of 10 and 20 photons was applied for the donor and acceptor channels respectively. Multimer events were removed from the donor channel by applying an upper limit threshold of 100 photons. Generally, 54% of molecules were donor only, 2% acceptor only and 44% doubly labelled. A dual channel burst search was used to extract doubly labelled bursts from each acquisition and find E and S with one or two Gaussian fits. The apparent donor-acceptor distance was calculated by R〈E〉=R0(E−1−1)16 where R0 is 53 Å. Burst variance analysis (BVA) was performed as previously described61 and implemented in Jupyter Notebooks using FRETbursts113. Bursts were divided into sub-bursts (n = 7 photons) and the standard deviation calculated for each sub-burst population over the time period of individual bursts. Accessible volume (AV) modelling was performed using the FRET-restrained positioning and screening (FPS) tool116. The three radii model was used with dye parameters: R1 = 11 Å, R2 = 3 Å and R3 = 1.5 Å for Cy5 and R1 = 6.8 Å, R2 = 3 Å and R3 = 1.5 Å for Cy3. Both dyes were modelled with a linker length of 14 Å and linker width of 4.5 Å. Distances from dye mean points were measured in PyMol96.

sec.title: In vitro transcription
sec.p: For in vitro frameshifting assays we cloned a 184 nt DNA fragment containing the TMEV slippery sequence and the RNA stimulatory element into a frameshift reporter plasmid that contained the T7 promotor, EMCV internal ribosome entry site (IRES) for translation initiation and coding sequence for SUMO protein. The sequence was inserted such that if translation occurred in the 0-frame a truncated version of the SUMO protein (17 kDa) would be the product. If -1 PRF occurs, then the full-length SUMO protein would be the translation product (26 kDa). Frameshift assay DNA plasmids were linearised with NdeI prior to run off transcription with T7 RNA polymerase (prepared in-house). Messenger RNAs were recovered by phenol:chloroform extraction (1:1 v/v) and concentrated by ethanol precipitation before aqueous resuspension. mRNA purity was assessed by gel electrophoresis and concentration determined by absorbance at 260 nm.

sec.title: Frameshift assays (in vitro translation)
sec.p: Messenger RNAs were translated in Flexi rabbit reticulocyte lysate (RRL) (Promega). Typical reactions were 10 µL composed of 66% (v/v) RRL, 25 µM amino acids (lacking methionine) and 0.2 MBq [35S]-methionine. tRNAs were charged with amino acids for 10 mins at 30 °C prior to addition of the mRNAs and 2A protein. Reactions were incubated at 30 °C for 1 hr. Translation was quenched by the addition of 10 volumes of 2x Laemmli’s sample buffer and boiled for 5 mins at 95°C. Translation products were assessed by 15% SDS-PAGE. Dried gels were exposed to a Storage Phosphor Screen (PerkinElmer) and the screen scanned in a Typhoon-5 using Phosphor imaging mode. Frameshift assays were repeated twice.

sec.title: Data Availability
sec.p: Crystallographic data and refined atomic models for the 2A-RNA complex have been deposited to the Worldwide Protein Data Bank (wwPDB) under accession code 9RVP. Small-angle X-ray scattering data has been deposited to the Small Angle Scattering Biological Data Bank (SASBDB) under accession codes SASDWQ5 (2A protein only), SASDWR5 (RNA only) and SASDWS5 (2A-RNA complex).

caption.title: The PRF stimulatory element from TMEV is a protein-pseudoknot complex
caption.p: a, Schematic diagram of -1 PRF in the cardioviruses. Frameshifting is conditional on the virally encoded 2A protein. The 2A protein (lilac) binds to the structured RNA stimulatory element (black, predicted stem loop) stalling the elongating ribosome at the mRNA entry channel whilst the slippery sequence (yellow) is positioned in the decoding centre. tRNAs (green) may uncouple and recouple in the -1 frame, prior to continuation of the ribosome.

b, Sequence details of the TMEV frameshift site. Numbering starts from slippery sequence (yellow). The stimulatory element is predicted to form a 7 bp stem loop (purple). Conserved GGxG and CCC motifs are highlighted (dark blue).

c, The effect of -1 PRF on viral gene expression. Leader protein (L) and capsid proteins (VP4, VP2, VP3, VP1) are encoded 5' of the -1 PRF site (indicated by black arrow) whereas the replicative proteins (2B, 2C, 3AB, 3Cpro – protease, 3Dpol – RNA polymerase) are encoded 3' of the -1 PRF site. Frameshifting results in the truncation of the viral polypeptide creating a short 2A-2B* fusion protein which down-regulates expression of the viral replicative proteins. Up to 85% of elongating ribosomes are diverted into the -1 frame — the highest known frameshifting efficiency.

d, 1.9 Å X-ray crystal structure of the 2A-RNA complex reveals that the RNA adopts a pseudoknot fold, not a stem-loop, when bound to 2A. Electron density (2FO-FC) within 1.2 Å of the refined models is shown in three views. 5' and 3' nucleotides not involved in base pairing are shown in grey, stem 1 (S1) in blue, stem 2 (S2) in purple, and loops (L1, L2) in cyan. Disordered nucleotides in L2 are shown as dashed line.

caption.title: Structural features of the RNA pseudoknot in complex with 2A
caption.p: Close-up views illustrating key regions of the RNA pseudoknot. The structure is shown as sticks, modelled into 2FO-FC electron density (grey mesh) contoured at 0.64 e-/Å3 (2.0 RMSD). (Centre) Topological diagram and cartoon representation of the 2A-RNA pseudoknot complex with base identity indicated. S1 consists of three non-consecutive G-C Watson-Crick base pairs comprised of the conserved GGxG and CCC triplet motifs, supported by the arginine loop (R85 and R87) and ‘G-clamp’ (G27) of 2A. The flipped base (U19) allows the formation of S1. Details of hydrogen bonding in S1 are shown. L1 is a single nucleotide (C21). S2 is a seven Watson-Crick base paired A-form RNA helix. L2 is mostly disordered. The 5' end of the RNA pseudoknot interacts with W89 through π-π interactions.

caption.title: The RNA stimulatory element switches conformation from stem-loop to pseudoknot upon 2A binding
caption.p: a, b, SEC-SAXS envelope with plots showing alignment between experimentally collected SAXS data (blue circles) and calculated data from structural models (red line), and the pair-distance distribution P(r) allowing the determination of Rg and Dmax. a, RNA in isolation, supporting a stem-loop model. b, 2A-RNA complex with X-ray crystal structure fitted to the data.
c, d, Schematic diagrams showing smFRET RNA reporter construct design using the Cy3 (cyan) and Cy5 (yellow) FRET pair.

e, f, Corrected FRET efficiency (E) histograms, data combined from three biological repeats of the e, end reporter and f, internal reporter RNAs. Corrected average FRET efficiencies (E) and number of molecules (n) are reported in each histogram. Gaussian fits to our data are show as dashed curves for two Gaussians and a solid blue line for a single Gaussian fit. R2 = 0.99 for all gaussian fits. Showing data for (upper) RNA in isolation, (middle) RNA in the presence of 0.5 µM wild type 2A and (lower) RNA with 0.5 µM inactive 2AR85A/R87A.

caption.title: The RNA does not spontaneously convert between multiple stable conformations
caption.p: (Left) 2D ALEX histograms of stoichiometry (S) against FRET efficiency (E) after filtering out the donor and acceptor only populations. The number of molecules in each dataset (n) is indicated. Data was collected from three independent experiments and combined. (Right) Corresponding burst variance analysis (BVA) contour plots assessing conformational dynamics of the RNA stimulatory element. Bursts were divided into sub-bursts of seven photons and the standard deviation calculated for each sub-burst population, indicated by black triangles. A standard deviation of sub-bursts greater than the theoretical shot-noise-limited variance (dashed black curve) suggests dynamics.

a-c, end reporter RNA (5' Cy5 and 3' Cy3). d-f, internal reporter RNA (5' Cy5 and Cy3 positioned on U31). a,d, RNA reporters in isolation. b,e, in the presence of 0.5 µM wild type 2A. c,f, in the presence of 0.5 µM inactive 2AR85A/R87A.

caption.title: Pseudoknot formation depends on stem 1 sequence
caption.p: a, Schematic diagrams showing the location of mutated nucleotides in stem 1 (S1).

b, EMSA analysis of the effects of S1 mutants on 2A binding. Experiments were performed with 50 nM RNA labelled with Cy5 at the 5' end. 2A concentrations were varied between 0-1.25 µM. Following non-denaturing gel electrophoresis, the gels were imaged with a Typhoon-5 scanner.

c, MST binding curves and approximate KD values using the same S1 mutant RNAs. The KD fit model was used to describe a 1:1 binding stoichiometry. Experiments were indepedently performed twice, with error bars indicating the standard deviation of the mean.

d, In vitro translation assay assessing the effects of 2A mutations on frameshifting. Schematic of in vitro translation assay and control mRNAs. The EMCV internal ribosome entry site (IRES) was used to initate translation. If elongation continues in the 0 frame the resulting protein product is ~17 kDa, created by premature termination at a stop codon. However, shifting into the -1 frame results in a ~26 kDa product. A non-slip (ns) control mRNA contains a mutant slippery sequence to prevent shifting into the -1 frame. The in-frame control (ifc) mRNA includes an additional mutation to bypass the premature stop codon. Translation reactions were carried out in the presence of 35S-Met, analysed by SDS-PAGE and visualised by autoradiography.

caption.title: Pseudoknot formation depends on stem 2 length, not sequence
caption.p: a, Schematic diagrams showing the location of mutated nucleotides in stem 2 (S2).

b, EMSA analysis of the effects of S2 mutants on 2A binding. Experiments were performed with 50 nM RNA labelled with Cy5 at the 5' end. 2A concentrations were varied between 0-1.25 µM. Following non-denaturing gel electrophoresis, the gels were imaged with a Typhoon-5 scanner.

c, MST binding curves and approximate KD values using the same S2 mutant RNAs. The KD fit model was used to describe a 1:1 binding stoichiometry. Experiments were indepedently performed three times, with error bars indicating the standard deviation of the mean.

caption.title: The second and third base pairs of stem 1 are critical for pseudoknot formation
caption.p: a, Schematic diagram showing the location of mutated nucleotides in stem 1 (S1) that disrupt base pair formation but not arginine-guanine interactions.

b, EMSA analysis of the effects of disrupting individual S1 base pairs on 2A binding. Experiments were performed with 50 nM RNA labelled with Cy5 at the 5' end. 2A concentrations were varied between 0-1.25 µM. Following non-denaturing gel electrophoresis, the gels were imaged with a Typhoon-5 scanner.

c, MST binding curves and approximate KD values using the same S1 mutant RNAs. The KD fit model was used to describe a 1:1 binding stoichiometry. Experiments were indepedently performed twice, with error bars indicating the standard deviation of the mean. The wild type panel is duplicated from Figure 5c for ease of comparison.

d, Corrected FRET efficiency (E) histograms with data combined from three biological repeats of S1 mutant RNAs. Corrected FRET efficiencies (E) and number of molecules (n) are reported in each histogram. Gaussian fits to our data are show as dashed curves for two Gaussians and a solid blue line for a single Gaussian fit. R2 = 0.99 for all Gaussian fits. Showing data for (upper) RNA in isolation, (lower) RNA in the presence of 0.5 µM wild type 2A.
